review.title: Learning Fuzzy Controllers in Mobile Robotics with Embedded Preprocessing
review.abstract: The automatic design of controllers for mobile robots usually requires two stages. In the first stage,sensorial data are preprocessed or transformed into high level and meaningful values of variables whichare usually defined from expert knowledge. In the second stage, a machine learning technique is applied toobtain a controller that maps these high level variables to the control commands that are actually sent tothe robot. This paper describes an algorithm that is able to embed the preprocessing stage into the learningstage in order to get controllers directly starting from sensorial raw data with no expert knowledgeinvolved. Due to the high dimensionality of the sensorial data, this approach uses Quantified Fuzzy Rules(QFRs), that are able to transform low-level input variables into high-level input variables, reducingthe dimensionality through summarization. The proposed learning algorithm, called Iterative QuantifiedFuzzy Rule Learning (IQFRL), is based on genetic programming. IQFRL is able to learn rules with differentstructures, and can manage linguistic variables with multiple granularities. The algorithm has been testedwith the implementation of the wall-following behavior both in several realistic simulated environmentswith different complexity and on a Pioneer 3-AT robot in two real environments. Results have beencompared with several well-known learning algorithms combined with different data preprocessingtechniques, showing that IQFRL exhibits a better and statistically significant performance. Moreover,three real world applications for which IQFRL plays a central role are also presented: path and objecttracking with static and moving obstacles avoidance.

metadata.title: Learning Fuzzy Controllers in Mobile Robotics with Embedded Preprocessing

sections.text: The automated design of mobile robot controllers usually requires two stages. In the first stage, sensory data is pre-processed or converted into high-grade and meaningful values of variables that are normally defined from expert knowledge. In the second stage, a machine learning technique is applied to obtain a controller that assigns these high-level variables to the control commands that are actually sent to the robot. In this paper, an algorithm is described that is able to embed the pre-processing phase into the learning phase to enable controllers to move directly from raw sensory data without expert knowledge. Due to the high dimensionality of sensory data, this approach uses quantified fuzzy rules (QFRL), which are capable of transforming low input variables into high-grade input variables, thereby reducing dimensionality by summarizing. The proposed learning algorithm, called Iterative Fuzzy Learning (FRL)

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: The control architecture of robots usually includes a set of behaviors that are implemented as controllers, capable of solving specific tasks such as motion control, following a moving object, avoiding collisions, etc. in real time. These behaviors are used as controllers whose results at any time (control commands) depend on the internal states of the robot and its environment. When the robot operates in real environments, both the data obtained by these sensors and the internal states of the robot are used. Therefore, it is necessary to use mechanisms that properly manage them. Using fuzzy rules is convenient to deal with this uncertainty, as they combine the interpretation and expression of the rules of the robot with the representation of uncertainties.

sections.heading: 2. Related Work
sections.text: The learning of robots is determined by the use of different methods of machine learning [4, 5], neural networks [6] and reinforcement of learning [7, 8]. Hibridations of them, such as the neural networks produced by the ant, are also covered by the theory of evolution.

Initializing the antecedent part of a rule requires obtaining the most similar linguistic label for a given fuzzy membership function (called mask label). As the maximum granularity of linguistic labels in the antecedent part of a rule is not limited, the function maskToLabel (Fig. 7) is used to obtain the most appropriate linguistic label. This function uses a similarity measure defined as [28]: similarity of labeling in the antecedent part of a rule that is labeled.

sections.heading: 4.7. Selection and replacement
sections.text: The selection was made according to the binary tournament strategy. The replacement follows a stationary approach. The new individuals and those of the previous population are merged, and the best Popmax individuals are selected for the next population.

sections.heading: 4.8. Epoch loop
sections.text: An epoch is a series of iterations at the end of which a new rule is added to KBcur. The stop criterion of each epoch (inner loop in Fig. 2) is the number of iterations, but this limit varies according to the following criteria: If the number of iterations reaches itmin, the algorithm stops if there are consecutive iterations (which are counted by equality) without changing the best individual (Bestind). If the number of iterations reaches the maximum (itmax), then the algorithm stops regardless of the previous condition. When the epoch ends, the rule defined in bestind is added to KBcur. Furthermore, the examples covered with precision (according to the criterion in Eq. 11) are marked as covered by the algorithm (line 20, Fig. 2).

sections.heading: 4.9. Rule subset selection
sections.text: After the end of the iterative part of the algorithm, the performance of the obtained rule base can be improved by selecting a subset of rules with better cooperation with each other, using the rule selection algorithm described in [1]. The rule selection process includes the following steps: 1. # Rgp Generate rule bases, where # Rgp is the number of rules of the population obtained by the IQFRL algorithm (RBgp). Each rule base is encoded as follows: RBi = ri1 · · ri # Rgp, with: rij = 0, i f j > i1, i f ≤ i (17), where rij indicates whether the j-th rule of RBgp is contained in RBi (rij = 1) or not (r i j = 0). With this codification, RBi will contain the best i-rules of RBgp, since these rules are classified in decreasing order of their individual suitability.

sections.heading: 5. Results
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 5.1. Experimental setup
sections.text: The proposed algorithm was validated with the behaviour known in mobile robotics wall following. The main objectives of a controller for this behaviour are: to maintain a suitable distance between the robot and the wall in order to move at the highest possible speed, and to implement smooth control actions. Player / Stage robot software [30] was used for testing on the simulated environments and also for connecting with the real robot Pioneer 3-AT. This real robot was equipped with two laser scanners with an amplitude of 180 and a precision of 0.5. It measures for each laser scanner scan. Without loss of generality, all examples and tests with the robot were based on its Right.The examples used for learning were generated for three different situations.

sections.heading: 5.2. Algorithms and parameters
sections.text: The following values were used for the parameters of the evolutionary algorithm: ME = 0.02, DOFmin = 0.001, α f = 0.99, Pcross = 0.8, popmax = 70, itmin = 50, itcheck = 10, itmax = 100, σbd = 0.01, σv = 0.1 and Pmin = 0.17. Pmin is a parameter that has a high influence on the performance of the system. A single value of Pmin was used in tests obtained by Eqs. 7 and 8 in case of errors for each sequence is a label (Eq. 8). Linguistic value A5, 1d indicates a low distance, while A 4, 1b indicates that the bar sector is formed by the front and right sides of the robot. Therefore, the rule describes a situation where the robot is too close to the wall, and if it continues, it will collide.

sections.heading: 7. Conclusions
sections.text: This paper describes a new algorithm that is capable of learning controllers with embedded pre-processing for mobile robotics. Conversion of low variables into high variables is done using QuantifiedFuzzy Propositions and Rules. In addition, the algorithm includes linguistic labels that are defined by multiple granularity without limiting the granularity. The algorithm has been extensively tested with the transformative behavior both in multiple simulated environments and on a Pioneer 3-AT robot in two real-world environments. Results were compared with some of the best known algorithms for learning controllers in mobile robotics. Non-parametric signature tests were conducted that showed a very good and statistically significant performance of the IQFRL approach.

sections.heading: Appendix A. IQFRL for Classification (IQFRL-C)
sections.text: This section describes the modifications necessary to adapt the IQFRL algorithm to classification problems.

sections.heading: Appendix A.1. Examples and Grammar
sections.text: The structure of the examples used for classification is very similar to that described in expression 4: el = (d (1),.., d (Nb), velocity, class) (A.1), where class is the class of the example. Furthermore, the consequent production (production 3) of grammar (fig. 4) must be modified to: sequence 3 − → Fcwo Fc is the linguistic name of the class. The output variable (class) has a granularity g # classc.

sections.heading: Appendix A.2. Initialization
sections.text: The sequence of rules is initialized as Fc = A γ c, where γ is the class that represents the example. When initializing a new individual, only those examples are used whose class differs from the standard class (A fc).

sections.heading: Appendix A.3. Evaluation
sections.text: For each individual (rule) of the population the following values are calculated: • True Positives (tp): - # tp = icher case (tp): - # tp = icher case is the class following the j-th rule, and DOF j (el) is the DOF of the j-th rule for the example el. # tp represents the number of examples correctly classified by the rule. - tpd = icher expression of confidence in the DOF j (el): Cl = C j, i.e. the sum of the DOFs of the examples leading to # tp.- tp = # tp + tpd / # tp • False positive case (fp): - # fp = icher case is clearly defined.

sections.heading: Appendix A.4. Mutation
sections.text: For classification purposes, the probability that an example corresponds to the output of a rule (Eq.7) is called binary. Thus, in order to select the example (donkey) to be used for the mutation, the following criteria are used: • For generalization, the probability that an example (el = donkey) is chosen is: P (el = donkey) = 1 − ∑ j DOF j (el) · Trust j ∑ j DOF j (el) (A.5), where trust j is the security (Equation A.2) of the j-th individual. This probability measures the precision with which the individuals of the population use the example el.Finally, the sequence is mutated taking into account the class of examples covered by the individual. Thus, the probability that the consequence of the individual j-change is into the class Cγ is defined as follows: P (j | Cγ) = сl DOF j (el): Cg = Cayl DOF j (el): Cayl DOF DOF (el): Cayl DOF DOF (el) (el) (el).

sections.heading: Appendix A.5. Performance
sections.text: Tables A.15 and A.16 show the number of rules learned through the IQFRL-C classification method, and the complexity of the rules learned in terms of the mean and standard deviation of the number of sentences and granularities for each input variable; the number of rules for each situation is very low, resulting in a very interpretable knowledge base; in addition, the complexity of the rules is also low, as the number of sentences and granularities learned shows that the rules are very general; Table A.17 shows the confusion matrix for the learned classifier; the matrix was obtained as an average of a 5-fold cross-validation over the sentences; in addition, the performance of the classifier was analyzed with the accuracy and the Cohen approach [44]. Both measures are very close to 1, showing the high performance of the classifier achieved with IQL-C.

metadata.abstractText: The automatic design of controllers for mobile robots usually requires two stages. In the first stage, sensorial data are preprocessed or transformed into high level and meaningful values of variables which are usually defined from expert knowledge. In the second stage, a machine learning technique is applied to obtain a controller that maps these high level variables to the control commands that are actually sent to the robot. This paper describes an algorithm that is able to embed the preprocessing stage into the learning stage in order to get controllers directly starting from sensorial raw data with no expert knowledge involved. Due to the high dimensionality of the sensorial data, this approach uses Quantified Fuzzy Rules (QFRs), that are able to transform low-level input variables into high-level input variables, reducing the dimensionality through summarization. The proposed learning algorithm, called Iterative Quantified Fuzzy Rule Learning (IQFRL), is based on genetic programming. IQFRL is able to learn rules with different structures, and can manage linguistic variables with multiple granularities. The algorithm has been tested with the implementation of the wall-following behavior both in several realistic simulated environments with different complexity and on a Pioneer 3-AT robot in two real environments. Results have been compared with several well-known learning algorithms combined with different data preprocessing techniques, showing that IQFRL exhibits a better and statistically significant performance. Moreover, three real world applications for which IQFRL plays a central role are also presented: path and object tracking with static and moving obstacles avoidance.
